video_caption: The video begins with a black screen displaying green text that reads "How to Format an APA Style Paper using Word for Mac" and "Terrence D. Jorgensen Kennesaw State University." This is followed by a blue screen with the same text, along with the words "Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association" and "Sixth Edition." The scene then transitions to a black screen featuring a blue "W" logo, which is the logo for Microsoft Word. The video then shows a computer screen with the Microsoft Word application open, displaying a blank document ready for formatting. The interface of the application is visible, including the menu bar, toolbars, and the blank document area. The video concludes with the same view of the Microsoft Word application, indicating that the user is about to begin formatting the APA style paper.

The video showcases a computer screen displaying the Microsoft Word application interface. The interface is shown in various states, including a blank document with a blinking cursor, a text box with a blinking cursor, and a document with a single letter 'I' typed. The toolbar at the top of the screen features various options such as 'File', 'Edit', 'View', 'Insert', 'Format', 'Font', 'Tools', 'Table', 'Window', and 'Help'. The video also demonstrates the use of the 'File' menu, where options like 'New', 'Open', 'Save', 'Save As', 'Print', and 'Properties' are visible. The video provides a step-by-step guide on how to use the Microsoft Word application, highlighting the different features and tools available to the user.

The video showcases a sequence of actions performed within a Microsoft Word document interface. Initially, the document is blank, with the toolbar displaying various formatting options. The user navigates to the 'File' menu, selecting 'Page Setup' and then 'Margins,' adjusting the settings to 1.25 inches for the top, bottom, left, and right margins. Subsequently, the user accesses the 'Page Setup' dialog box, changing the paper size to 'Letter' and setting the orientation to 'Portrait.' The 'Margins' tab is revisited, with the user adjusting the top, bottom, left, and right margins to 1.25 inches. The 'Line Numbers' tab is then accessed, with the user setting the line spacing to 'Single' and enabling 'Line Numbers.' Throughout the video, the interface remains consistent, with the cursor moving to interact with the various options and settings. The video concludes with the 'Line Numbers' tab still open, displaying the adjusted settings.

The video showcases a computer screen displaying the Microsoft Word interface, specifically focusing on the 'Document' settings dialog box. The dialog box is open, revealing options for 'Section start,' 'Headers and footers,' 'Different first page,' 'Vertical alignment,' 'Line numbers,' and 'Borders.' The 'Apply to' dropdown menu is set to 'This document,' and the 'Default' button is highlighted. The 'OK' button is also visible. The background of the screen shows the Word toolbar with various tabs and options, including 'File,' 'Edit,' 'View,' 'Insert,' 'Format,' 'Font,' 'Tools,' 'Table,' 'Window,' and 'Help.' The cursor is seen hovering over the 'Line numbers' checkbox, indicating an intention to select or deselect this option. The video then transitions to a pop-up message asking, "Do you want to change the default settings? This change will affect all new documents based on the Normal.dot template." The message includes 'Yes' and 'No' buttons, with the 'Yes' button highlighted, suggesting the user's intention to confirm the change. The overall setting is a typical office environment, with the focus on the Word document settings and the user's interaction with the software.

The video showcases a sequence of actions performed within a Microsoft Word document interface. Initially, the screen displays a blank document with the Word toolbar visible at the top, featuring various formatting options such as font style, size, bold, italic, and underline. The user then types the letter 'I' into the document, followed by a period, and proceeds to insert a table with two columns and two rows. Subsequently, the user navigates to the 'Format' menu, selects 'Font,' and opens the 'Font' dialog box, where they adjust the font size to 12 and apply bold formatting. The video concludes with the user closing the 'Font' dialog box, leaving the document with the formatted text and table visible on the screen. Throughout the video, the environment remains consistent, with the focus solely on the Word document and its interface.

The video showcases a sequence of actions performed within a Microsoft Word document. Initially, the 'Font' dialog box is open, displaying various font styles and options such as 'Cambria (Phonetic Bold)' and 'Cambria (Phonetic Regular)' under the 'Font' tab. The user navigates through the font styles, selecting different options like 'Cambria (Phonetic Italic)' and 'Cambria (Phonetic Bold Italic)' before closing the dialog box. The scene then transitions to the main Word document interface, where the user selects the 'Font' tab again, this time focusing on the 'Font' dialog box's 'Font' section. The user scrolls through the list of font styles, highlighting 'Cambria (Phonetic Regular)' and 'Cambria (Phonetic Bold)' before closing the dialog box once more. The video concludes with the user opening the 'Paragraph' dialog box, adjusting the 'Indentation' and 'Spacing' settings, and then closing the dialog box, leaving the Word document interface ready for further editing. Throughout the video, the user's actions are methodical, focusing on customizing the document's text appearance and layout.

The video showcases a computer screen displaying the Microsoft Word application interface. The focus is on the "Paragraph" settings dialog box, which is open and visible in the center of the screen. The dialog box contains various options for adjusting paragraph alignment, indentation, and spacing. The user has selected the "Left" alignment option and set the indentation to 0.5 inches. The spacing is set to "Single" with a line spacing factor of 1.5. The "Don't add space between paragraphs of the same style" checkbox is checked. The background of the screen shows the Word toolbar with various formatting options, and the document area is blank. The video remains static, with no changes or movements observed throughout the sequence.

The video showcases a sequence of interactions with a Microsoft Word document on a computer screen. Initially, the document is displayed with a blank page and the Word interface visible, including the menu bar and toolbars. The user opens the 'Paragraph' settings dialog box, adjusting alignment, indentation, spacing, and other paragraph-related options. The dialog box is then closed, and the user navigates to the 'View' menu, selecting 'Draft' to change the document's view mode. Subsequently, the user opens the 'Insert' menu, revealing various options such as 'Web Layout,' 'Print Layout,' 'Full Screen Layout,' and 'Notebook Layout,' among others. The video concludes with the 'Insert' menu still open, highlighting the user's exploration of different view and layout options within the Word document. Throughout the video, the focus remains on the computer screen, with no visible people or environmental details beyond the software interface.

The video showcases a computer screen displaying the Microsoft Word application interface. The interface is set to a document titled "Document1," with the "Home" tab selected, indicating the user is in the editing mode. The document is formatted with the "Times New Roman" font, size 12, and the cursor is positioned at the beginning of the document, ready for text input. The "First Page Header" section is visible at the bottom of the screen, suggesting that the user is preparing to add a header to the first page of the document. The interface includes various toolbars and menus, such as "File," "Edit," "View," "Insert," "Format," "Font," "Tools," "Table," "Window," and "Help," providing access to a wide range of document editing features. The video captures the user's interaction with the software, highlighting the layout and functionality of Microsoft Word.

The video showcases a computer screen displaying a Microsoft Word document in the process of being edited. The document is in the header section, specifically the first page header, as indicated by the "First Page Header" label at the bottom of the screen. The text "Running head:" is typed in the header area, followed by the insertion of a colon. The user then proceeds to type the letter "I" in the header area, and subsequently, the text "ALL CAPS" is added after the colon, indicating that the running head should be in all capital letters. The interface of Microsoft Word is visible, with various tabs and options such as "Home," "Insert," "Layout," "Document Elements," "Tables," "Charts," "SmartArt," and "Review" displayed at the top of the screen. The cursor is seen moving across the document, reflecting the user's actions in editing the header. The background of the video is the typical Microsoft Word interface, with a focus on the document editing process.

The video showcases a step-by-step process of formatting a document in Microsoft Word. Initially, the document displays a running head in all caps, "Running head: ALL CAPS," at the top of the page. The user then proceeds to type the title "Title:" followed by a subtitle "Subtitle" below it. The next step involves centering the text, as indicated by the cursor hovering over the "Center Text" button in the toolbar. Finally, the user adds their name below the title and subtitle, completing the document's formatting. Throughout the video, the interface of Microsoft Word is visible, with various toolbars and options available for document editing. The background remains consistent, showing the typical layout of a Word document with a white page and blue toolbar.

The video showcases a step-by-step process of creating a document in Microsoft Word. It begins with a blank document, where the user types the title "Title: Subtitle" followed by "Name" and "Institution." The user then proceeds to format the document by adding a running head with the text "Running head: ALL CAPS" and a page number "1." The next step involves inserting a table with two columns and three rows, followed by the addition of the word "Abstract" in the first row of the table. The user then types the word "Title: Subtitle" again, this time in the second row of the table. The video concludes with the user typing the word "Introduction" in the third row of the table, completing the document's structure. Throughout the video, the user's actions are focused on formatting and structuring the document, with no visible people or environment details beyond the computer screen.

The video showcases a step-by-step guide on how to create a running head in Microsoft Word. It begins with a blank document, where the user inserts a title and subtitle, followed by the name and destination. The user then selects the text and applies the 'ALL CAPS' formatting. Next, the user navigates to the 'Insert' tab, selects 'Page Number,' and chooses 'Bottom of Page' with 'Plain Number 1' style. The user then clicks on the 'Header' tab, selects 'Edit Header,' and inserts the text 'Running ALL CAPS' into the header area. The user adjusts the font size and alignment, ensuring the running head is properly formatted. The video concludes with the running head successfully displayed at the top of the page, demonstrating the final result of the tutorial.

The video showcases a step-by-step guide on how to format a document in Microsoft Word. It begins with a blank document titled "ALL CAPS" and a subtitle "Title Subtitle" on page 1. The user navigates through the menu, selecting "Insert" and then "Page Break," followed by "Section Break (Next Page)" to create a new section. The document is then split into two pages, with the second page titled "References" on page 4. The user proceeds to adjust the paragraph settings, specifically the line spacing, to 1.5. Finally, the video demonstrates how to insert a citation, showing the formatted reference entry at the bottom of the page. Throughout the video, the focus remains on the document and the user's actions within the Word interface, providing a clear and concise tutorial on document formatting.

The video showcases a sequence of actions performed within a Microsoft Word document. Initially, the document displays a title "ALL CAPS" and a reference citation formatted in APA style, with the cursor positioned at the end of the citation. The user then navigates to the "Insert" tab and selects "Quick Parts," followed by "Field." This action opens a dialog box titled "Field," where the user selects "Reference" from the list of categories. Subsequently, the user clicks on the "OK" button, which closes the dialog box and inserts a reference field into the document. The video concludes with the reference field appearing in the document, indicating the successful insertion of the reference. Throughout the video, the interface of Microsoft Word is visible, with various toolbars and menus displayed at the top of the screen.

The video showcases a computer screen displaying a Microsoft Word document with a focus on the "References" section. The document is formatted with the title "ALL CAPS" at the top, followed by the word "References" and a citation example. The citation includes placeholders for author names, publication year, article title, journal title, volume number, and page numbers. The text is formatted in Times New Roman font, size 12, and the document is zoomed in to 140%. The Word interface is visible, showing various toolbars and options for editing and formatting the document. Throughout the video, the cursor is seen making adjustments to the citation example, specifically modifying the page number range from "page - page" to "page - page." The environment is a typical office setting, with the focus solely on the document and its formatting.

The video begins with a close-up of a computer screen displaying a Microsoft Word document, highlighting the 'References' section with a citation example. The scene transitions to the cover of the "Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association, Sixth Edition," featuring a blue background with green and white text. Following this, a slide titled "Getting Started in APA Style" appears, crediting Terrence D. Jorgensen, Laboratory Coordinator of the Psychology Department at Kennesaw State University, with reference material from the APA Publication Manual. The video then returns to the cover of the APA Publication Manual, emphasizing its title and edition. Finally, a black screen displays the text "How to Format an APA Style Paper using Word for Mac" by Terrence D. Jorgensen from Kennesaw State University, providing a clear instructional title for the content.
